skill.name: pci-compliance
skill.description: Implement PCI DSS compliance requirements for secure handling of payment card data and payment systems. Use when securing payment processing, achieving PCI compliance, or implementing payment card security measures.
skill.summary: Implement PCI DSS compliance requirements for secure handling of payment card data and payment systems.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Educational PCI DSS compliance skill. All static findings are false positives. The skill provides documentation and code examples for implementing payment card security requirements. No actual vulnerable code or malicious patterns present.

content.value_statement: This skill provides guidance on implementing PCI DSS requirements for secure payment processing. It covers encryption, tokenization, access controls, and audit logging to help achieve and maintain payment card industry compliance.
actual_capabilities: Generate PCI DSS compliance checklists based on the 12 core requirements
Provide code examples for encrypting cardholder data using AES-256-GCM
Explain tokenization strategies to reduce compliance scope
Implement access control decorators for payment data endpoints
Create PCI-compliant audit logging for cardholder data access
limitations: Does not provide legal advice or certification
Does not replace formal PCI DSS assessments
Does not include third-party payment processor integrations
Does not perform automatic compliance scanning

use_cases.title: Payment System Development
use_cases.description: Developers building payment processing systems use this skill to implement secure data handling, encryption, and access controls that meet PCI DSS requirements.

use_cases.title: Compliance Preparation
use_cases.description: Security engineers preparing for PCI DSS assessments use this skill to understand requirements, identify gaps, and implement necessary controls.

use_cases.title: Code Review for Payment Apps
use_cases.description: Code reviewers auditing payment applications use this skill to verify proper handling of cardholder data, encryption implementation, and audit logging.

prompt_templates.title: PCI DSS Requirements Overview
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the 12 core PCI DSS requirements? Provide a summary of each requirement category for implementing payment card security.
prompt_templates.scenario: Understanding the high-level PCI DSS framework

prompt_templates.title: Card Data Encryption
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to encrypt stored cardholder data (PAN) using AES-256-GCM in Python. Include key generation, encryption, and decryption.
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing encryption for stored card numbers

prompt_templates.title: Tokenization Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to implement tokenization for payment cards. Show code examples for creating payment method tokens and storing them instead of actual card numbers.

prompt_templates.prompt: How do I implement role-based access control for payment data endpoints in a web application? Show a Python Flask decorator example.

output_examples.input: What data should never be stored for PCI compliance?
What are the PCI compliance levels?
output: PCI DSS Compliance Levels (Based on Annual Transactions):
Level 4: Under 20,000 e-commerce or under 1 million total

best_practices: Never store CVV, track data, or PIN - these must be rejected at input and never persisted
Use tokenization to replace card numbers with reversible tokens, eliminating card data from your systems
Implement encryption using AES-256-GCM or equivalent strong cryptography for stored cardholder data
anti_patterns: Storing full card numbers in plaintext or with weak encryption
Logging card numbers or sensitive payment data without masking
Using default passwords or vendor-supplied credentials for payment systems

faq.question: What is the minimum encryption strength for PCI DSS?
faq.answer: PCI DSS requires strong cryptography including AES-256 or equivalent. Encryption must use industry-standard algorithms with strong key management practices.

faq.question: Can I use a hosted payment page to reduce compliance scope?
faq.answer: Yes, using hosted payment pages (like Stripe Checkout or PayPal) where card data never touches your servers significantly reduces PCI scope to SAQ A.

faq.question: What is the difference between SAQ A and SAQ D?
faq.answer: SAQ A is for merchants using fully outsourced payment handling with minimal requirements. SAQ D is for organizations that store, process, or transmit card data with full PCI DSS requirements.

faq.question: Do I need to encrypt card data in transit?
faq.answer: Yes, PCI DSS requires encryption (TLS 1.2 or higher) for all transmission of cardholder data across public networks.

faq.question: How long must I retain audit logs for PCI compliance?
faq.answer: PCI DSS requires retaining audit logs for at least one year, with 90 days immediately accessible and the remaining 9 months in archive.

faq.question: What access controls are required for cardholder data?
faq.answer: PCI DSS requires unique user IDs, role-based access control, least-privilege principles, and multi-factor authentication for remote access to cardholder data environments.
